channel.title: Ocean Dynamics and Mixing
channel.description: The Ocean Dynamics and Mixing group at the University of Southampton is comprised of faculty, postdoctoral fellows and students. The focus of our group is on ocean observations with the aim of understanding these measurements and comparing with theoretical understandings of the ocean.

item.title: PhD Opportunities
item.description:
There are several PhD opportunities available within our group - for physical oceanography, oceanography and biological oceanography using autonomous underwater vehicles, and development of new micro technology for ocean observation.

For more details, see Opportunities.

item.title: Oceans and Climate event in London
item.description:
The three keynote talks were delivered by Eleanor Frajka-Williams, Stephen Belcher (Chief Scientist, Met Office) and Martin Visbeck (Physical Oceanographer, IFM-Geomar Kiel) on the topics of ocean observations, oceans and weather, and human and ocean interaction. Following the talks, there was a panel with the speakers as well as Joerg Wiedermann (UoS) and Bablu Sinha (NOC).

For more information about the event, as well as footage and photos, see https://www.southampton.ac.uk/news/events/2017/09/25-oceans-and-climate-public-lecture.page

item.title: MerMEED & OSMOSIS results
item.description: A few of us went to the 49th Liege Colloquium which was the 3rd edition of Marine Turbulence. It was a lovely workshop-sized conference in a beautiful venue. Gwyn and Eleanor presented early results from the MerMEED project, and Xialong and Christian from OSMOSIS.

item.title: FreshWATERS balloon launch
item.description:
We had one of our test balloon launches for the FreshWATERS project in May. It required an early start (before 6am) followed by a car chase of the GPS coordinates given by the balloon.

Photos of the launch (and recovery) in Galleries.

item.title: EGU Early Career award
item.description: At the 2017 European Geophysical Union general assembly, Eleanor Frajka-Williams was awarded with the Outstanding Early Career Scientist award for Ocean Sciences. Unfortunately, she was in the Southern Ocean and couldn’t be there to receive the award in person.

item.title: Piece in the Conversation about Boaty McBoatface
item.description:
Alberto wrote a piece for the Conversation while we were on the RRS James Clark Ross, crossing Drake Passage towards the Weddell Sea.

It has a bit about the project Dynopo (Dynamics of the Orkney Passage Outflow), and also about the Autosub Long Range (ALR). These vehicles have been in development for a while, but after the internet poll to name the new polar research vessel came up with a top naming choice of “Boaty McBoatface”, the ALRs got renamed Boaty McBoatface.

Read more on the Conversation: https://theconversation.com/mcboatface-lead-scientist-how-famed-submarine-will-help-unlock-the-causes-of-deep-sea-warming-74797.
